The congressional budget process determines the maximum budget authority for annual appropriations, including DHS, through a two-stage process. Congress sets overall spending totals in the annual concurrent resolution on the budget, which are then allocated among the appropriations committees as 302(a) allocations for enactment in annual appropriations bills. In the budget process, appropriations committees allocate 302(a) discretionary funds to subcommittees for each bill. These allocations, known as 302(b) allocations, must not exceed the 302(a) allocation to enforce budget discipline. Adjustments to 302(b) allocations can be made by the Appropriations Committee throughout the year as bills progress towards enactment.
